questions.text: On October 16, 1846, the first public demonstration of general anaesthesia for surgery using ether was conducted. Hence forth, October 16 is regarded as
questions.solution:
In Boston, Massachusetts, on October 16, 1846, William T.G. Morton conducted the first publicised demonstration of general anaesthesia for surgical operation using ether. The surgeon was John Warren and the operation was the removal of a mass under the jaw of Gilbert Abbott.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology, 6th edition, chapter 1, pg no 2.

choices.text: Soda lime in the breathing system

questions.text: Among the following, which is a method of active humidification of the airway
questions.solution:
Humidifiers are important in order to preserve the physiology of the respiratory tract.

Humidification can be established by either active or passive methods.

Option c: nebulisers are classified as methods of active humidification



Reference: Primary FRCA in a box, pg 24.

choices.text: symptoms and signs of drug allergy

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of type A adverse drug reactions?
questions.solution:
Adverse drug reactions can be defined as one of the two types:

Type A:

  • dose dependent
  • common
  • extension of known pharmacological effect

Type B:

  • dose independent
  • uncommon
  • symptoms and signs of drug allergy

The most important type to the anaesthetist is type B, which encompasses both anaphylactic and anaphylactoid reactions.

Reference: Physics, Pharmacology and Physiology for Anaesthetists, Matthew E. Cross, second edition, pg 151.

questions.text: A patient in the intensive care unit who is in a catecholamine depleted state. Which of the induction agents can further cause adrenal suppression?
questions.solution:
Even a single induction dose of Etomidate has been found to have adrenal suppression effects in patients to 20 hours post induction.

Reference: Stoelting’s pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice 5th edition pg 160-197

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of hiatal hernia and acid reflux is undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia. She has a family history of malignant hyperthermia of her distant relative. Which of the following agent is allowed to be used in anaesthesia induction
questions.solution:
Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a life-threatening hypermetabolic state of skeletal muscle that is triggered by the volatile inhaled anaesthetics-isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane-and by the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine. Malignant hyperthermia presents as an increase in carbon dioxide production, acidosis, cardiac arrhythmias, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia. Death can occur if the MH crisis is not managed appropriately and early in the course of the episode. The mainstay of treatment is i.v. dantrolene.

Reference: stoelting’s anaesthesia and coexisting diseases sixth edition pg 635

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents has seizure inducing ability?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, 0.15 to 0.3 mg/kg IV, has minimal effects on the duration of electrically induced seizures and thus may serve as an alternative to drugs that decrease the duration of seizures (propofol, thiopental) in patients undergoing electroconvulsive therapy.

Propofol has been associated with myoclonic movements.

Reference: stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice 5th edition pg 169.

questions.text: A 32 year-old man is apprehensive of general anaesthesia and prefers a regional anaesthetic. Decision is made to conduct spinal anaesthesia for the repair of inguinal hernia along with midazolam and opiod to allay anxiety. But suddenly he complains of chest tightness. This is attributed to the effect of :
questions.solution:
opioids like fentanyl even given as bolus doses can cause chest rigidity or tightness, respiratory depression and sedation. They should be administered as small aliquots and be titrated to effect.

Reference: Stoelting’s pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition, page no 223

questions.text: A local numbing cream is sometimes applied to the skin before attempting an intravenous access in paediatric patients. Which of the following local anaesthetics is combined to produce this cream?
questions.solution:
EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetics) cream was formulated to overcome the obstacles presented by intact skin. It consists of a mixture of lidocaine and prilocaine bases in an emulsion. Depth of analgesia (usually <0.5 cm), duration of action (usually <2 h), and amount of drug absorbed depend on application time, dermal blood flow, and total dose administered. Typically, 1 to 2 g of cream is applied per 10-cm2 area of skin. Dermal analgesia sufficient for inserting an intravenous catheter requires about 1 h under an occlusive dressing.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition pg 267.

questions.text: All procedures that generate aerosols have been minimised or avoided during the covid -19 pandemic, to prevent the spread. Which of the following has a high possibility of generating respiratory aerosols?
questions.solution:
Nebulization with local anesthetic will aerosolize the virus and increase chances of viral transmission. Hence nebulization is avoided.

Option a: Rapid sequence induction and tracheal intubation (with cricoid pressure) to be done in the first attempt. Ensure adequate neuromuscular blockade to avoid bucking that can increase aerosolization. Immediately inflate the tracheal tube cuff before starting ventilation.

Option c: preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for five minutes is recommended in COVID patients due to pulmonary involvement and high chances of desaturation.

Option d: Video-laryngoscope (if available) can be used to improve intubation success. Also, it may increase the distance between the patient's airway and that of the anaesthesiologist who performs the intubation.

Reference:https://www.ijaweb.org/article.asp?issn=0019-5049;year=2020;volume=64;issue=4;spage=259;epage=263;aulast=Malhotra

questions.text: The pandemic of SARS COVID-19 has put tremendous pressure on the existing medical healthcare and supplies. There has been an increased demand on Oxygen, a very vital part of the therapy for these patients. The most common method of manufacturing oxygen commercially is by
questions.solution:
• The most common method of manufacturing oxygen commercially is by the fractional distillation of liquefied air. This method produces oxygen which is over 99% pure.
  • alternatively, oxygen concentrators containing zeolite adsorbents can be used. Zeolite selectively adsorbs nitrogen and so delivers oxygen that is 90 93% pure. The major contaminant is argon. oxygen concentrators are commonly used in aircraft, submarines, military field hospitals and at home.

Reference: Dorsch - Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment, Edition 5, page no 110

questions.text: A 35 years female presented with swelling in front of the neck. FNAC revealed carcinoma of thyroid. She underwent a total thyroidectomy. Post operative day 2, a diagnosis of tetany was made and she was started on calcium supplementation. The test indicating towards the diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Hypocalcaemia from parathyroid removal during total thyroidectomy can present in post operative period as tetany.

  • Presentation-may present with signs of neuromuscular excitability, tingling around the mouth, or tetany. may progress to fits or ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Diagnosis-carpopedal spasm (flexed wrists, fingers drawn together) may be precipitated by cuff inflation (Trousseau’s sign). Tapping over the facial nerve at the parotid may cause facial twitching (Chvostek’s sign).

Reference: Oxford handbook of Anaesthesia, edition 4, page no 577

questions.text: Post operative nausea and vomiting are a common outcome to many of the anaesthetic agents used. Increased incidence of PONV can occur in
questions.solution: Reference: Morgan, page no 1292

questions.text: Remifentanyl is an ideal drug for Total intravenous anesthesia. This is because of the property:
questions.solution:
Due to its ester linkages it is susceptible to hydrolysis by blood and tissue non specific esterases resulting in rapid metabolism. This allows rapid termination of effect and referral from anesthesia.

  • Highly lipid soluble.
  • Pharmacokinetics uninfluenced by liver and renal failure.
  • It is not a substrate for hydrolysis by pseudocholinesterases
  • Context sensitive half time is around 4 minutes and is independent of the duration of infusion.

Reference: Comparative pharmacology for Anesthetist, page no.35

questions.text: Vomiting is a common side effect following use of opioids. This is attributed to all of the following mechanisms except
questions.solution:
Gastric emptying time is slowed via central and peripheral mechanisms.

Increased tone and decreased propulsive action of both small and large intestine results into constipation.

Vomiting is induced by following mechanisms

  • CTZ stimulations.
  • Decreased gastrointestinal motility.
  • Prolonged gastric emptying time.

Reference: Comparative pharmacology for Anesthetist, page no.42

questions.text: The following are the openings in the diagram, which of them is matched wrong?
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box 223

questions.text: The highest value of Minimum Alveolar concentration of the following Inhalational agents is
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no.188

choices.text: (tidal volume - dead space) x respiratory rate

questions.text: Alveolar ventilation is given by
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation. Volume of gas entering the alveoli per minute; normally about 4–4.5 l/min. Equals (tidal volume minus dead space) × respiratory rate; thus rapid small breaths result in a much smaller alveolar ventilation than slow deep breaths, even though minute ventilation remains constant.

Reference: FRCA A TOZ, page no.26

questions.text: Which of the following is a slow onset intravenous anaesthetic drugs
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no.178

questions.text:
Carbon dioxide absorbers are used in anaesthetic breathing systems to allow rebreathing of exhaled gases. The chemical reaction involved is
CO2 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 + H2O
The reaction is
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no.62

questions.text: Iatrogenic contributions to maternal supine hypotension syndrome can be minimized by
questions.solution:
Supine hypotension syndrome is defined as a decrease in mean arterial pressure of more than 15 mm Hg with an increase in heart rate of more than 20 beats/min and is often associated with diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, and changes in mentation.

Reducing the compression of the inferior vena cava and abdominal aorta with left tilt may mitigate the degree of hypotension and help maintain uterine and fetal blood flow. This is accomplished by positioning the patient laterally or by elevating the right hip 10 to 15 cm (with a historical goal of 15 degree left-tilt) with a blanket, wedge, or table tilt.

Reference: miller’s anaesthesia 9th edition pg 2009.

questions.text: What is the recovery position
questions.solution: the recovery position is the position opted for the patient following anesthesia. The left lateral position with a head low aims to decrease chances of aspiration. The secretion when head low can collect in the oropharynx and can be suctioned out, avoiding aspiration.

questions.text: You are called for declaration of brain death in a patient. Which of the following criteria is not used for declaring brain death from among the following?
questions.solution:
Absent spinal cord reflex is not a criteria for brain death.

Brain death is defined as irreversible cessation of all brain function. Spinal cord function below C1 may still be present.

Generally accepted clinical criteria for brain death include the following:

  • Coma
  • Absent motor activity, including no decerebrate or decorticate posturing
  • Spinal cord reflexes may be preserved
  • Absent brainstem reflexes, including no pupillary, corneal, vestibuloocular (caloric), or gag (or cough) reflexes
  • Absence of ventilatory effort, with the arterial CO2 tension at least 60 mm Hg or 20 mm Hg above the pretest level (Positive apnea test)

Confirmatory test findings (not mandatory but may assist in diagnosis)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of brainstem auditory evoked potentials
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545144/

questions.text: A 39 year old male patient with moderate degree burns before 1 week is to be anaesthetised. Use of which of the following anaesthetic drug is absolutely contraindicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
In patients with significant burns (>20% TBSA), injury and disruption of neuromuscular end plates occurs, followed by up regulation of acetylcholine receptors. Beyond 15-48 h after significant burn injury, succinylcholine can produce lethal hyperkalemia. This risk for succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia persists for up to 2 years following burn injury.

Options a,b: Propofol and atracurium have no contraindications, and opioids (option d) should be used with caution as burns patients require frequent procedures and thus can land in opioid tolerance.

Ketamine used for burn dressings can also lead to tolerance and increased dose requirements if used frequently.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition pg 837.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with uncontrolled hypertension presents for an elective dialysis access creation. Which of the following techniques is not suited for attenuating the hypertensive response to intubation?
questions.solution:
Chronic hypertensive patients show wide fluctuations in blood pressure on induction (hypotension) and intubation (hypertension). Duration of laryngoscopy <15 seconds has been shown to prevent this hypertensive response to intubation. Intubation performed under deep anesthesia is also shown not to produce significant rise in blood pressure. There are several techniques that can be used to prevent sudden spikes in blood pressure during intubation. Topical airway anesthesia, β-blockers like esmolol 0.3 to 1.5 mg/kg, short-acting opioids like fentanyl 2.5 to 5 μg/kg, intravenous preservative-free lidocaine at 1.5 mg/kg have all been shown to be effective in attenuating the hypertensive response.

Reference: lippincott’s anaesthesia review chapter 11

questions.text: A 30-year-old male during a road traffic accident, sustained a bilateral femur and pelvic fracture 2 days ago. In the last 24 hours, he has developed breathlessness, requiring 100% FIO2 to maintain an oxygen saturation in the high 80s and is now becoming more confused and disoriented. Physical exam reveals petechiae on the anterior chest wall, arms, and conjunctiva. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Features of fat embolism syndrome (as defined by Gurd)

Major

  • Respiratory symptoms—tachypnoea, dyspnoea, bilateral crepitations, haemoptysis, diffuse shadowing on CXR.
  • Neurological signs—confusion, drowsiness.
  • Petechial rash.

Minor

  • Tachycardia.
  • Retinal change—fat or petechiae.
  • Jaundice.
  • Renal—oliguria or anuria.

Laboratory

  • Thrombocytopenia.
  • Sudden decrease in hb by 20%.
  • Raised ESR.
  • Fat macroglobulaemia.

Reference: oxford handbook of anaesthesia 4th edition pg 446.

questions.text: A 30 year female patient presents with a goitre in front of the neck. She is planned for total Thyroidectomy. While examining the airway, which of the following measurement cannot be assessed?
questions.solution:
Predictors of difficult airway include

Adequate mouth opening- A normal inter incisor gap or mouth opening is more than 5 cm or 3 finger breath.

Thyromental distance or Patils test- Measured from the upper border of Thyroid cartilage to the chin, in complete neck extension. Normal is more than 6.5 cm. In Thyroid swelling like goitre the upper border of the Thyroid cartilage or the whole cartilage is not palpable, so this measurement becomes impossible.

Sterno mental distance of SAUVA test measured from maintain stern to chin. Normal value is more than 12.5 cm. This is considered as the single most important predictor of difficult airway.

Reference: Rashid khan, edition 4, page no 24

questions.text: A preterm neonate is taken up for Surgery for bilateral choanal atresia. Which ASA-PS class does the patient come under?
questions.solution:
Neonates are obligate nasal breathers. A bilateral choanal atresia is a emergency condition, causing respiratory obstruction.


Reference: Oxford's handbook of anaesthesia, edition 4, page no 1220

questions.text: A 32 year old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She is a known case of schizophrenia and is on mood stabilisers, lithium. For how long should her medications be stopped prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
Lithium is an inorganic ion used as a mood stabilizer in the treatment of bipolar affective disorder. It has a low therapeutic ratio, with an optimal plasma concentration of 0.4-1.0mmol/L.

  • Lithium mimics Na+ in excitable tissues, being able to permeate voltage-gated ion channels, and accumulates inside cells, causing slight loss of intracellular K+ and partial depolarization.
  • Chronic use causes weight gain, renal impairment, and hypothyroidism.
  • Lithium toxicity occurs at >1.5mmol/L and is exacerbated by

hyponatraemia, diuretic therapy, and renal disease. Features include lethargy/restlessness, nausea/vomiting, thirst, tremor, polyuria, renal failure, ataxia, convulsions, coma, and death. Haemodialysis is effective.

  • Lithium potentiates both depolarizing and non-depolarizing NMB; nerve stimulator monitoring should be used.

Reference: Oxford's handbook of anaesthesia, edition 4, page no 269

questions.text: A preeclamptic patient is planned for cesarean section. She is planned for general anaesthesia and rapid sequence intubation. This involves avoiding
questions.solution:
Induction, rapid sequence ('Crash induction'). Induction of anaesthesia in which risks of regurgitation and aspiration of gastric contents are minimised by:

  • presence of emergency drugs and equipment, a tipping trolley and skilled assistance. use of a rapidly acting iv induction agent and suxamethonium to achieve rapid muscle relaxation. application of cricoid pressure. avoidance of manual inflation of the lungs by face-mask to prevent inflation of the stomach and thus increase risk of regurgitation. Preoxygenation is therefore required to prevent hypoxaemia during apnoea until tracheal intubation is achieved.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 302

questions.text: Propofol is a commonly used induction agent. It's main side effect is pain on injection. This can be minimised or avoiding by employing the following means:
questions.solution:
IV anaesthetic agent, first used in 1977 and introduced into clini- cal practice in 1986. Thought to produce anaesthesia by binding to GABAA receptors and potentiating the action of endogenous GABA. Fospropofol is the phosphate prodrug of propofol and as such has a slower onset of action. Pain on injection is common; it may be reduced by prior administration of opioid analgesic drugs, injecting into a large vein, and prior injection of, or mixing with, lidocaine.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 482

questions.text: Among the non depolarising muscle relaxants, a few exhibit vagolytic properties. They are
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: Atracurium and cis- Atracurium exhibit isomerism properties. What differentiates them?
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: The muscle relaxant of longest duration of action
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: In neuromuscular monitoring, a peripheral nerve is stimulated and the response is recorded according to different patterns. The most commonly used nerve is
questions.solution:
commonly used sites:

  • ulnar nerve: electrodes are placed along the ulnar border of the forearm, with assessment of thumb adduction. More sensitive than the diaphragm and vocal cords to neuromuscular blocking drugs.
  • facial nerve: electrodes are placed anterior to the tragus of the ear, with assessment of facial muscle contraction. Underestimation of the degree of blockade is common, because of direct muscle stimulation and relative insensitivity of the facial muscles to neuromuscular blocking drugs.
  • accessory nerve: one electrode is placed behind the mastoid process and the other at the posterior border of sternomastoid. Stimulation causes con- traction of sternomastoid and trapezius muscles and is easier to see than following stimulation of the facial nerve. Asystole has followed tetanic stimulation when the upper electrode was placed anterior to the ear, attributed to stimulation of the vagus via the cranial root of the accessory nerve.
  • tibial nerve: electrodes are placed behind the medial malleolus, with assessment of big toe plantar flexion.
  • common peroneal nerve: electrodes are placed lateral to the neck of the fibula, with assessment of foot dorsiflexion.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5th, page no 406

questions.text: The subjective signs of neuromuscular recovery include
questions.solution:
sustained head lift for 5 s is the most useful clinical indicator of adequate neuromuscular function (under 30% blockade). Other suggested indicators include the ability to open the mouth, pro- trude the tongue, cough, maintain sustained hand grip, and achieve adequate tidal volume, vital capacity (15 ml/kg) and inspiratory pressure (−20 cm H2O).

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 407

questions.text: The Inhalational agents are influenced by a number of patient and environmental factors. The factors that decreases the Minimum Alveolar Concentration or increasing the potency of the agent are
questions.solution:
• MAC is reduced by:
  • other depressant drugs (e.g. opioids, sedatives, other inhalational agents).
  • CNS depletion of catecholamines, e.g. by

α-methyldopa, reserpine.

  • hypothermia.

hypoxaemia/hypotension.

  • pregnancy, possibly due to increased progesterone levels.
  • extremes of age.
  • MAC is increased in: children.
  • hyperthermia.
  • hyperthyroidism.
  • chronic alcoholism.

It is unaffected by duration of anaesthesia, sex, acidaemia/ alkalaemia, hypercapnia or hypocapnia.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 381

questions.text: Methoxyflurane is a Inhalational anaesthetic that is seldom in use. This is because of its property of
questions.solution:
Methoxyflurane causes maximum fluoride release. This is neurotoxic and can cause vasopressin resistant high output renal failure.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 305

questions.text: One of the common peri operative complications of anaesthesia is hypothermia due to impaired thermoregulation. Following are the effects of perioperative hypothermia,
questions.solution:
Hypothermia. Core temperature below 36°C.

Effects:

  • cardiovascular:

- reduced cardiac output (a 30% reduction at 30°C).

- J waves (positive deflections at the end of QRS complexes) may appear on the ECG

- ventricular arrhythmias at 30°C, VF at 28°C.

- vasoconstriction. Vasodilatation occurs below

20°C.

- increased blood viscosity.

- increased haematocrit below 30°C. Thrombocyto-

penia may be caused by sequestration, mainly hepatic. Fibrinolytic activity and prothrombin time increase. DIC may occur.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 292

choices.text: Posterior cranial fossa surgery in sitting position

questions.text: Air embolism is a complication seen during anesthesia and surgery. All the following are risk factors for Air embolism except
questions.solution:
Air embolism. Introduction of air bubbles into the circulation, usually into veins (although arterial air embo- lism has been caused by prolonged flushing of arterial lines in neonates). A potential risk when venous pressure is lower than atmospheric pressure. It may occur during any surgery when an open vein is raised above the heart; it is particularly likely in neurosurgery with the patient in the sitting position since the dural sinuses do not collapse. May also occur during insertion or removal of a CVP line (minimised by tilting the patient head-down during the former and using occlusive dressings as opposed to gauze in the latter). Procedures involving insufflation or injection of gas, e.g. laparoscopy, epidural anaesthesia using loss of resistance to air, laser surgery with gas-cooled probes, may also lead to embolism.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 18

choices.text: Abrupt fall in end tidal co2

questions.text: Air embolism is a complication seen during anesthesia and surgery. The clinical features of a venous Air embolism is
questions.solution:
Air embolism. Introduction of air bubbles into the cir-culation, usually into veins.

Clinical features:

  • reduced cardiac output.
  • tachycardia.
  • cyanosis.
  • bronchospasm and pulmonary oedema may occur.

Dyspnoea, coughing and chest pain are common in

the awake patient.

  • tinkling sounds on auscultation, e.g. with an oesoph-

ageal/precordial stethoscope; large amounts of air may cause a 'mill-wheel' murmur. May be detected by a precordial Doppler probe or transoesophageal echocardiography, although the extreme sensitivity of these techniques may reveal many tiny bubbles of disputed clinical significance.

  • sudden reduction of end-tidal CO2 due to increased dead space and decreased cardiac output. End-tidal nitrogen monitoring has also been used to monitor air embolism.
  • raised pulmonary artery resistance and pressure.
  • signs of right ventricular strain on the ECG; ven-

tricular ectopics or fibrillation may occur.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 18

questions.text: A patient during induction and intubation of anesthesia suddenly had high ventilation pressures. The capnograph shows a graph resembling shark fin appearance. The likely condition you are facing is
questions.solution:
Measurement of end tidal carbon dioxide concentration and is graph

is useful by studying

  • phase 1: zero baseline during inspiration; a raised

baseline indicates rebreathing

  • phase 2: dead-space gas (containing no CO2) is followed by alveolar gas, represented by a sudden rise to a plateau. Excessive sloping of the upstroke

may indicate obstruction to expiration - bronchospasm

  • phase 3: near-horizontal plateau indicates mixing of alveolar gas. A steep upwards slope indicates obstruction to expiration or unequal mixing, e.g.

COPD

  • phase 4: rapid fall to zero at the onset of inspiration.
  • additional features may be present:

- superimposed regular oscillations corresponding to the heartbeat (Fig. 30d).

- small waves representing spontaneous breaths between ventilator breaths, e.g. if neuromuscular blockade is insufficient


Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 101

questions.text: Bispectral index monitor is used to monitor
questions.solution:
Bispectral index monitor. Cerebral function monitor that uses a processed EEG obtained from a single frontal electrode to provide a measure of cerebral activity. Used to monitor anaesthetic depth in an attempt to prevent awareness. Produces a dimensionless number (the BIS number) ranging from 100 (fully awake) to 0 (no cerebral activity). The algorithm used to calculate the BIS value is commercially protected but is based on power spectral analysis of the EEG, the synchrony of slow and fast wave activity and the burst suppression ratio. Targeting a BIS number of 40-60 is advocated to reduce awareness and allow more rapid emergence from anaesthesia, although the evidence does not support its routine use.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 70

questions.text: Monitoring of respiration during anaesthesia can be done by
questions.solution:
monitoring: O2 failure warning device, output and delivery O2 analyser, and disconnection detection by expired tidal volume measurement, capnography and airway pressure measurement. Monitoring of volatile agent. All alarms set at appropriate values and enabled. Infusion devices checked and alarms set.

  • patient monitoring: clinical observation of colour, pupils, respiration, pulse and response to surgery, chest auscultation, urine output and blood loss when appropriate

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no; 385

questions.text: While infiltrating local anaesthetics, to prolong the duration of action adrenaline is added. This should be however avoided in
questions.solution:
Addition of epinephrine or less commonly phenylephrine causes vasoconstriction at the site of administration. The consequent decreased absorption reduces the peak local anesthetic concentration in blood, facilitates neuronal uptake, enhances the quality of analgesia, prolongs the duration of analgesia, and limits toxic side effects. However they cannot be used in parts having end arterial supply, as it will cause distal necrosis.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 267

questions.text: Among the commonly used local anaesthetics, more cardiotoxic potential is observed in
questions.solution:
Unintended intravascular injection of bupivacaine during regional anesthesia may produce severe cardiovascular toxicity, including left ventricular depression, atrioventricular heart block, and life-threatening arrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 271

questions.text: The Tuffier's line is considered as the site of administration of sub arachnoid block. This level corresponds to the intervertebral space
questions.solution:
Because the spinal cord normally ends at L1, lower nerve roots course some distance before exiting the intervertebral foramina. These lower spinal nerves form the cauda equina ('horse's tail')Therefore, performing a lumbar (subarachnoid) puncture below L1 in an adult (L3 in a child) usually avoids potential needle trauma to the spinal cord; damage to the cauda equina is unlikely, as these nerve roots float in the dural sac below L1 and tend to be pushed away (rather than pierced) by an advancing needle


Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 966

questions.text: The most common complications of spinal anaesthesia is
questions.solution:
Neuraxial blocks produce variable decreases in blood pressure that may be accompanied by a decrease in heart rate. These effects generally increase with more cephalad dermatomal levels and more extensive sympathectomy. Profound hypotension may result from arterial dilation and venous pooling combined with bradycardia. These effects are exaggerated if venous pooling is further augmented by a head-up position or the weight of a gravid uterus.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 967

questions.text: Post dural puncture headache is a common complication following neuraxial blockade. The definitive management involves
questions.solution:
Conservative treatment involves recumbent positioning, analgesics, intravenous or oral fluid administration, and caffeine. An epidural blood patch is an effective treat- ment for PDPH. It involves injecting 15 to 20 mL of autologous blood into the epidural space at, or one interspace below, the level of the dural puncture. It is believed to stop further leakage of CSF by either mass effect or coagulation. The effect is usually immediate and complete.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 992

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a field block?
questions.solution:
A field block is a local anesthetic injection that targets terminal cutaneous nerves .Field blocks are used commonly by surgeons to minimize incisional pain and may be used as a supplementary technique or as a sole anesthetic for minor, superficial procedures. Anesthesiologists often use field blocks to anesthetize the superficial cervical plexus for procedures involving the neck or shoulder; the intercostobrachial nerve for sur- gery involving the medial upper extremity proxi- mal to the elbow (in combination with a brachial plexus nerve block); and the saphenous nerve for surgery involving the medial leg or ankle joint (in combination with a sciatic nerve block).

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 1000

questions.text: The common complication associated with brachial plexus block may be incidence of an ipsilateral pneumothorax. This is highest in
questions.solution:
Supraclavicular black is associated with an increased incidence of pneumothorax due to the close proximity of the apical pleura and its accidental puncture.


Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 1009
